Wow, your Chinese language is really really good. Having localized accent is fun. There is no right accent, southern and northen accent are very different, with Beijing having the very odd "er" and "eng" accent. Taiwan accent is softer. Malaysian and Singapore Chinese accent are "hard" with excessive used of the fourth tone.

A Chinese from southern China here, normally, 你吃饭了吗 or "Have you eaten yet" are used to greet someone who you are familiar with, such as neighborhoods, friends, roommates etc. at breakfast/lunch/dinner time, 你去哪里/你怎么在这里/你在这里干嘛 or "where are you going" / "why are you here" / "what are you doing here" are perfect and widely-used phases to start a conversation with someone you have known at anytime. If you and your friends don't meet each other for a long time, maybe a couple of days/weeks/months/years, you can say: 好久不见，最近过得怎么样/好久不见，最近去哪里了or "long time no see, how are you these days" / "long time no see, where have you been". Basically, Chinese people show their caring for someone before starting a conversation with others.

I don't think it's difficult to learn Chinese as long as I find a good way and insist on it. Otherwise, how can those young Chinese children master it?

I can share my experience as a person who has studied Chinese for 6 years:

1. First of all, we should have a good attitude and not rush to success

2. Learning Chinese spelling

3. Learn to use Chinese dictionary as a tool to look up every Chinese character you don't know

3. Find some basic Chinese learning materials and start reading and reciting. When I learn Chinese, I often buy some bilingual reading materials in both Chinese and English online, which are all e-books very cheap. Here is the link
https://payhip.com/b/ykR2

4. This method may seem simple, but it is really effective,

Because the brain's language expression is mostly unconscious. If you can't recite skillfully, you will be stuttered in the daily communication process, which is very embarrassing. But when you recite a large number of Chinese sentences (not necessarily fully understand the meaning) and then communicate with the Chinese people, some daily expressions will come out very easily. For example, I recited one at the beginning Some simple children's Chinese and English books (some classic fairy tales) have learned some simple Chinese expressions within three months. I have been able to express my meaning in simple Chinese. After one year's persistence, I have been able to communicate normally in Chinese in my work and daily life. I also know many Chinese friends, who are very enthusiastic. Of course, I am still learning Learn more complex expressions, such as idioms and some sentences that can't be translated in English. Learning a language can well experience the differences and fun between different cultures. When you can speak Chinese more and more skillfully, you will well understand their culture and philosophy, so recite a lot!

Chinese is colorful painting,  in contrast English is black-white painting.
Chinese is the most concise language, best for poem. Here is something that can only be done in Chinese language:
藏头诗 ( 藏頭詩趣談,  http://blog.udn.com/H101094880/131727114 ): 
「月中秋會佳期  下彈琴誦古詩  中不聞鐘鼓便  深方知星斗移  少神仙歸古廟  中宰相運心機  時到得桃源洞  與仙人下盤棋」
( In simplified Chinese:
「月中秋会佳期  下弹琴诵古诗  中不闻钟鼓便  深方知星斗移  少神仙归古庙  中宰相运心机  时到得桃源洞  与仙人下盘棋」 ) 
This looks like gibberish, but hidden in it is actually a beautiful poem if you can find the scheme。The real poem after you reorganize somehow, it become:

八月中秋會佳期，月下彈琴誦古詩。寺中不聞鐘鼓便，更深方知星斗移。
多少神仙歸古廟，朝中宰相運心機。幾時到得桃源洞，同與仙人下盤棋。
( In simplified Chinese:
「八月中秋会佳期，月下弹琴诵古诗。寺中不闻钟鼓便，更深方知星斗移。
多少神仙归古庙，朝中宰相运心机。几时到得桃源洞，同与仙人下盘棋。」) 

The trick is, the first word of each sentence is a part of the last word of previous sentence, except for the first sentence where you use the last sentence. For example, the first word “月” of the second sentence is part of ”期“,  the last word of the first sentence.

Lastly but not the least importantly, isn't the poem a beautiful one?

One thing that I have to say to people who are afraid to speak to native speakers in the language that they're learning: native speakers will often find it cute and endearing to hear you making mistakes in their language.  Most of my friends that I've made in different languages always kind of giggle and praise me and then correct what I've said and tell me how adorable I am.  It's simultaneously strange, comforting, sweet, and slightly irritating lol.  But don't worry about being embarrassed. A lot of native speakers love it.

Just started courses at the Confucius Institute in an advanced group where there are people fluent in CN, who've been learning for 3-5 years... Um. Yeah. I feel way outmatched. Still easier than learning in CN where kids of 10 years of age speak far better than my mates here. ;)
I too am on the Mandarin learning path, thank you for such an authentic and informative video xx
No culture shock because Shanghai is not real China..

I am Chinese and I need a friend, I can teach you to speak Chinese, you can teach me to learn English, my email:
sentris@foxmail.com

I've been studying French for about 7 years at school. When I spoke French though, I would start to stammer, too. It is _so_ true that you really have to put the language to the test for you to improve quickly! This is true for every foreign language

Hi guys, I'm a native Chinese speaker. I'm now a senior in a university in Tianjin and I would love to improve my spoken English. If anyone is interested in improving their spoken Chinese and willing to help me with my English, feel free to contact me. We can either skype or meet in person if you're also in Tianjin. 欢迎大家来找我语言交换呀~

I've been studying Chinese for 6 years now and I've noticed some pronunciation problems. When you were pronouncing 找 the zh should be a bit sharper, something like the j sound in jam (I'm not English native so it's harder for me to find the right words) and the 听起来... the t sound should also be a bit sharper, it sounded more like "jing" to me. I understood everything, but I just wanted to point this out. :) fighting :) i know Chinese is hard and I appreciate everyone who can learn it and speak. I hope my comment will be helpful. :)
girl how come you're mispronouncing every other word?? study up sis
